724891f-a.text:
York Avenue (Avenue A), east side, north from 68th Street. The building on the N.E. corner of 68th Street is only slightly in the picture; it is the old "Century" apartment house.
68th to 69th Streets is the old site of Jones Woods Coliseum (to about 1895, known in 1891 as Empire City Coliseum). 1294-1304 Avenue A, from 69th to 70th Streets, were built after 1902. That block used to be Washington Park. From 70th to 71st Streets may be seen the old cigar factories. The white building, from 71st to 72nd Streets, is the new plant of P. Lorillard Company, built since 1920 on the site of the old Clausen malt house. Everything from 68th to 71st Streets is about to be demolished.
February 13, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

714221f-b.text:
(1)
68th Street, from but not including York, to but not including  Marie Curie Aves.
February 13, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)

Central Brewing Plant. In the foreground appears York Ave.
June 30, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as No. 1, as seen from the N.W. corner of East 67th Street at York Ave. Note children's play house No.437 East 67th Street" in the foreground.
September 13, 1925.
P. L. Sperr.

724893f-a.text:
Construction of New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College, York Avenue, east side, from 68th to 70th Streets, seen from 67th Street between First and York Avenues.
July 31, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

724894f-a.text:
New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College, nearing completion, York Avenue, east side, from 68th to 71st Streets, showing also 68th Street at west side of York Avenue.
On the S.W. corner of 68th Street, adjoining the tennis courts, the old Seidenberg factory has recently been demolished.
June 30, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

714223f-a.text:
68th Street, west of, adjoiing, and at the north-west corner of York Avenue. The large buildings in the background are the Cornell University-New York Hospital buildings.
March 5, 1933
P. L. Sperr, photographer

724890f-a.text:
York Ave., east side, at East 68th Street, showing north of that point the new buildings comprising the New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College.
1935.
George Jirnek.

724889f-a.text:
York Avenue (formerly Avenue "A"), at the S.W. corner of East 68th Street, showing the easterly and northerly sides of the recently constructed Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases. At the right the photographer shows a westward view on the south side of East o8th Street, towards First Avenue where St. Catherines Park and the Julia Richmond High School appear.

November 13, 1939
Gift of George Jiranek
New York Public Library
Photostat Division

724896f-a.text:
York Avenue, east side, from East 68th to 71st Streets, showing a night view of the New York Hospital and Cornell Medica) College buildings. This photo is hnohtheastward from a rooftop at 430 East 67th Street and shows in the foreground a portion of the recently completed Memorial Hgspital for the Treatment of Cancer.
Fall, 1939
Gif of George Jiranek
Photostat Division
New York Public Library

1558173.title: York Avenue - East 68th Street
1558173.folder: York Avenue - East 68th Street, Manhattan, NY

1558176.title: York Avenue - East 68th Street
1558176.folder: York Avenue - East 68th Street, Manhattan, NY

724887f-a.text:
York Avenue at 68th street, from clearing on N. E. corner, showing demolition of the Seidenberg factory building, which used to be the Robt. Burns Cigar factory; it was built around 1905. Adjoining it on York Avenue an old skating rink has been made over into tennis courts.

The view is from the clearing where the "Central" apartment house stood and where the new New York Hospital will rise. The little building on the N.W. corner will stay.

August 26, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

724888f-b.text:
(1)
York Avenue (Avenue A) at N.E. corner of 68th Street, showing "The Central", an apartment house built in 1902, and about to be demolished.
Prior to about 1895 this block was occupied by Jones Woods Coliseum, known in its last few years as Empire City Coliseum. The name York Avenue was officially adopted late in 1928.
February 13, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
York Avenue at N.E. corner of 68th Street, seen from the southwest and showing the other corners.
The new New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College buildings, nearing completion, occupy the land east of York Avenue from 68th to 70th Streets.
On the S.W. corner, adjoining the tennis courts in the foreground, the Seidenberg factory has been demolished.
June 30, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

724888f-a.text:
(1)

724892f-a.text:
York Avenue (Avenue A), west side, from 68th to 69th Streets. The third building from the corner, on 68th Street, goes through the block to 69th Street; it used to be a stable belonging to Thomas Crimmins, Contractor.
February 13, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

724895f-b.text:
Construction of New York Hospital -- Cornell Medical College, York Avenue, east side, from 68th to 71st Streets, showing S.E. corner of 68th Street.
This particular view is nearly straight north on York Avenue, from the roofs on the west side at 66th Street.
July 31, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
New York Hospital -- Cornell Medical College, construction nearly completed, York Avenue, east side, from 68th to 71st Streets, showing S.E. corner of 68th Street. Eleven months
have passed since the preceding view was taken.
The playground of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, shown on the right foreground of the preceding view, has now given place to tennis courts.
June 30, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
